data.title: Edition 13 (NAIA Championships Preview)
data.meta_description: COMING UP: at NAIA Volleyball National Championships, presented by CNOS Foundation, Sioux City, Iowa – vs. No. 11 Westmont, Tuesday (11/27), 3:15 p.m. (CT),
data.text:
Women's Volleyball 11/21/2012 2:42:00 PM Mike Safford

Volleyball Yote Notes - Edition 13 (NAIA Championships Preview)

COMING UP: at NAIA Volleyball National Championships, presented by CNOS Foundation, Sioux City, Iowa – vs. No. 11 Westmont, Tuesday (11/27), 3:15 p.m. (CT), vs. No. 2 Texas-Brownsville, Wednesday (11/28), 1 p.m. (CT), vs. St. Francis, Thursday (11/29), 1 p.m. (CT), single-elimination bracket play, Friday-Saturday.

LAST WEEK: NAIA Volleyball National Championships Opening Round vs. Menlo (W 3-0)

STATS / LIVE VIDEO: Live Stats of all three Pool Play matches for the Lady Yotes will be available via the Dakstats Tournament Site (http://tinyurl.com/ac3qbm9), while pay-per-view video of the Single-Elimination Bracket Play will be available Friday and Saturday at http://www.watchnaia.com.

TRAVEL INFORMATION: The Lady Yotes will be traveling to Sioux City via Southwest Airlines on Friday, returning to the Treasure Valley after the tournament. The team will be staying at the Holiday Inn-Downtown Sioux City (712-277-9400). For fans heading to the National Championships, All-Tournament passes are available for $35.00 at the Tyson Events Center/Gateway Arena, with single-day tickets available for $10.00.

LADY YOTES HEADED BACK TO IOWA: For the fifth-straight season, The C of I has earned a berth to the NAIA National Championships, presented by CNOS Foundation, in Sioux City, Iowa. The Lady Yotes are one of 12 teams who earned a berth to the Final Site on the Missouri River through the Opening Round process, joined by 12 other teams who were seeded through to the Final Site based on the final Top-25 poll. The C of I was grouped in Pool B – playing a trio of afternoon matches Tuesday-Thursday to determine the 12 teams which will comprise Bracket Play for the National Championship.

HISTORY AT NATIONALS: It marks the eighth time in program history that the Lady Yotes have earned a berth to the National Championships. In 2000, the Lady Yotes earned an at-large berth to Nationals in West Palm Beach, Fla., going 1-3 in Pool Play, while in 2005, the squad traveled to San Diego, Calif., going 2-2 in Pool Play. The 2006 season saw the Lady Yotes go 2-1 in Pool Play in Columbia, Mo., losing a quarterfinal play-in match against host Columbia. In 2008, the Yotes defeated Menlo (Calif.) in the Opening Round, going 0-3 in Pool Play in Sioux City, Iowa, while in 2009, The C of I was seeded through to Sioux City, going 2-1 in Pool Play, losing a four-set quarterfinal play-in against Texas at Brownsville. In 2010, the Yotes swept St. Thomas (Texas) in an Opening Round match, going 2-1 in Pool Play, losing in three sets to Cal Baptist in a quarterfinal play-in match. Last season, the Yotes defeated Carroll (Mont.) in three sets in an Opening Round match, going 2-1 in Pool Play, before defeating Rocky Mountain (Mont.) in five sets in a quarterfinal play-in match, before losing to Columbia (Mo.) in four sets in the national quarterfinals. With their Opening Round win over Menlo, the Yotes have a record of 16-16 in tournament play.

LADY YOTES UNSEEDED: For the fifth time in their eight trips to Nationals, the Yotes will not be one of the 12 seeded teams in the tournament. In 2006, the Lady Yotes were seeded No. 7, in 2009, the squad was seeded No. 8, while last season, the Yotes were seeded No. 12.

OPENING ROUND RECAP: Of the 12 matches played on Saturday, 10 of the host teams picked up victories – with St. Francis (Ill.) defeating Doane (Neb.) and Cal State San Marcos winning at Vanguard (Calif.). Four teams – Georgetown (Ky.), Madonna (Mich.), CSU-San Marcos, and Bellevue (Neb.) all won in four sets, while St. Francis and Missouri Baptist winning in five sets.

SURVEYING THE POOLS: The six pools (designated A through F) were determined by a final seeding following the Opening Round matches, with teams 1-12-13-24 in Pool A, 2-11-14-23 in Pool B, 3-10-15-22 in Pool C, 4-9-16-21 in Pool D, 5-8-17-20 in Pool E, and 6-7-18-19 in Pool F. The four highest-seeded teams that win their respective pool will earn an automatic spot in Bracket Play, while the remaining first or second-place teams in their pools will meet in four play-in matches to fill out the national quarterfinal field.

ABOUT WESTMONT: The Yotes open up tournament play on Tuesday against Westmont, from the always-tough Golden State Athletic Conference. The Warriors (24-8) will be making their eighth trip to Nationals, but their first since the 2002 season. The California school is led offensively by All-GSAC outside hitter Madison Serrano (3.47 k/s, 3.21 d/s, 46 aces) and All-GSAC middle blocker Ciara Turner (2.93 k/s, 0.79 b/s), with All-GSAC setter Candice Adema (10.75 a/s) running the attack, while libero Kristin Schroeder (4.43 d/s, 26 aces) leading the defense. It marks the first-ever meeting between the two schools.

ABOUT TEXAS-BROWNSVILLE: Day 2 in Sioux City will see the Yotes face the defending NAIA champions, Texas-Brownsville, ranked No. 2 in the final national poll. The Scorpions (26-1), champions of the Red River Athletic Conference, have lost just nine sets all season – with their lone loss a five-set thriller at Concordia-Irvine. UTB is primarily a foreign team – as 10 of their 12 players hail from outside the United States, with every member of their normal rotation coming from either Brazil or Sebria. Outside hitters Danica Markovic (3.28 k/s, 2.63 d/s, 70 aces) and Michelle Marques (2.84 k/s, 2.47 d/s, 0.77 b/s, 34 aces), along with blockers Ana Guerra (2.13 k/s. 1.80 b/s) and Vanja Joksic (2.42 k/s, 0.78 b/s) all are six-foot or taller – leading an attack that hits at a .304 percentage and averages 2.71 blocks and 2.60 aces per set. Setter Katarina Bursac (10.73 a/s) has been outstanding this season, as has libero Paula Barrios (4.40 d/s, 32 aces). It is the second meeting between the teams, as the Yotes and UTB met in the 2009 National Championships, with the Scorpions topping C of I in four sets.

ABOUT ST. FRANCIS: The C of I closes out Pool Play against St. Francis of Joliet, Ill., the champions of the Chicagoland Collegiate Athletic Conference. The Saints (37-6) will be making their ninth trip to Nationals, but their first since 2002, and bring a 23-match win streak against NAIA foes. USF is solid in the passing game, as setter Ashley Richards (10.39 a/s, 50 aces) was the CCAC Setter of the Year and libero Dana Wettergren (4.95 d/s) was CCAC Libero of the Year. The Saints are led by Jazzmyne Robbins (3.61 k/s) and Megan Mowery (2.80 k/s),part of an attack that averages 13.43 kills a set. It is the first-ever meeting between the schools.

AGAINST THE REST OF THE FIELD: The Lady Yotes are 0-3 against teams at the Final Site – dropping three-set matches to No. 1 Concordia (Calif.), No. 4 Biola (Calif.), and Cal State San Marcos.

PERFECT IN THE OPENING ROUND: The victory on Saturday over Menlo helped the Yotes improve to 4-0 all-time in Opening Round matches – all in the J.A. Albertson Activities Center. In the four matches (twice against Menlo, also against Carroll and St. Thomas), the Lady Yotes have won 12 of the 13 sets played.

PORTER SISTERS EACH CLOSING IN ON 1,000: The NAIA Championships will see both of the Yotes’ Porter sisters have an opportunity to each crack 1,000 in their respective top stat categories. For junior Janel Porter (Eagle, Idaho / Rocky Mountain HS), she needs just four digs to become the 11th player in program history to record 1,000-digs in a C of I uniform. For freshman Sierra Porter (Eagle, Idaho / Rocky Mountain HS), she needs 76 assists to become the tenth player to record 1,000 assists in a career.

PEACOCK, HULSEY LEADING THE WAY: The Coyote senior starters have been crucial in the success of the squad this season – as both Jessica Peacock (Summertown, Australia / San Diego State U.) and Torrey Hulsey (Sutter, Calif. / West Virginia U.) have put up huge numbers. Peacock, who leads the team with 307 kills, has recorded at least nine kills in each of her last 15 games, while logging five double-doubles this season. Hulsey has recorded at least eight kills in each of her last 14 games and four-or-more blocks in six of her last 10 matches.

20-WIN SEASONS: With their victory on Nov. 10, the Lady Yotes secured their eighth-straight season with at least 20 wins. During the run of 20-win seasons (including the school record 35-4 record in 2006), The C of I has a combined record of 211-51.

YOTES CLINCH PLAYOFF BERTH: The Lady Yotes clinched their 14th-straight playoff appearance with a victory on Oct. 12 against Evergreen – their 12th-straight trip to the postseason under head coach Liz Mendiola. The C of I advanced to regional playoffs in 2001, 2003, and 2005-07, the NAIA National Tournament in 2000, 2005-06, and 2008-12, claiming CCC Tournament titles in 2005, 2006, 2008, 2009, and 2012.

FINAL TOP-25 POLL: The C of I climbed one spot to No. 14 in the final regular-season Tachikara-NAIA Top-25 poll, released on Nov. 11. The Lady Yotes received 380 voter points from the 23 conference and unaffiliated grouping voters. Concordia (Calif.) holds the top spot, followed by Texas at Brownsville, Columbia (Mo.), Biola (Calif.), and Embry-Riddle (Fla.). Three other C of I opponents’ – No. 11 Westmont, No. 20 Cal State San Marcos and No. 22 Vanguard are in the poll, with St. Francis, Eastern Oregon, and Southern Oregon receiving votes.

HOME STREAK SAFE UNTIL 2013: For the seventh-straight year, the Lady Yotes recorded a perfect home record in CCC play, extending their home win streak in conference action to 71. Since 2005, the Lady Yotes have won 98-of-101 matches in the Activities Center, while posting a 189-39 all-time record in the building, including a sparkling 137-15 record under head coach Liz Mendiola.

LEAGUE LEADERS: As a team, the Lady Yotes lead the CCC in blocks per game (2.18), ranking second in hitting percentage (.222), opponents’ hitting percentage (.145), and kills per set (12.92). The squad is No. 3 in assists per set (11.90) and aces per set (1.72), ranking No. 8 in digs per set (14.54). Individually, five C of I players are in the Top-10, with Torrey Hulsey No. 6 in hitting percentage (.284), No. 8 in blocks per set (0.87), and No. 10 in kills per set (2.78), and Jessica Peacock No. 5 in kills per set (3.16) and hitting percentage (.286), ranking no. 9 in aces per set (0.33). Liz Myers (Middleton, Idaho / Middleton HS) is No. 3 in blocks per set (1.06) and No. 10 in hitting percentage (.258), Sierra Porter is No. 2 in assists per set (9.94), and Janel Porter (Eagle, Idaho / Rocky Mountain HS) is No. 6 in digs per set (5.02).

RECORD BOOK: Coyote middle blocker Liz Myers has cracked the Coyote career Top-10 list in blocks, ranking No. 8 all-time with 309, while setter Sierra Porter is No. 10 all-time with 924 assists. Libero Janel Porter is closing in on becoming the 11th member of the 1,000-dig club, with 996 digs in her three years with the Yotes.

GAME RECAP – C OF I 3, MENLO 0: Jessica Peacock had 13 kills helping The C of I improve to 4-0 all-time in Opening Round matches, as the Lady Yotes advanced to their fifth-straight NAIA Volleyball National Championships Final Site with a 25-21, 25-20, 25-21 victory over Menlo College, Saturday inside the J.A. Albertson Activities Center. The Lady Yotes won for the 98th time in 101 matches at home dating back to 2005 and evened their NAIA Championships all-time record at 16-16. The C of I jumped out to a 13-9 lead in Set 1, only to watch as the Oaks took advantage of four Coyote errors to rattle off five straight points, taking a 14-13 lead. Tied 18-18, the hosts used a Torrey Hulsey kill to take the lead, closing out the set with a Liz Myers kill and a Myers-Kylee Nawahine (Fruitland, Idaho / BYU-Hawaii) block. The Yotes got two Peacock kills in a 6-1 start to Set 2, but a Nicole Yap kill got Menlo as close as 22-20, before a Nawahine kill, a Janel Porter ace, and a Sofia Anxo (Reno, Nev. / U. of Nevada) spike ended the set. Courtney Calicdan rocketed a pair of kills in a 6-1 run for the Oaks early in Set 3 to take a 15-10 lead, but C of I responded, tying the score at 20-20 on a Peacock kill. The hosts closed out the match with four-straight points, taking advantage of a hitting error to complete the sweep. Hulsey had nine kills, Anxo had seven kills, and Myers added six kills and three blocks in the win for the Coyotes. Sierra Porter had 40 assists and five digs, with Janel Porter adding 14 digs for The C of I. Calicdan led the Oaks with 12 kills, Yap added 11 kills and 16 digs, and Stephenie Monderine had 17 assists for Menlo.

ABOUT THE COACH: Liz Mendiola is in her 12th season head coach of the Lady Yotes. During her tenure, the Coyotes have advanced to 11 consecutive CCC tournaments – winning seven regular-season and seven postseason tournament titles, advanced to four NAIA regional tournaments – winning titles in 2005 and 2006, and made trips to the NAIA National Championships in 2005, 2006, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011, and 2012. Last season, the squad won their sixth-straight CCC regular-season title and advanced to the NAIA Tournament Final Site in Sioux City, Iowa, advancing to the NAIA national quarterfinals – finishing the season ranked No. 7 in the NAIA Top-25 Coaches Poll. During her career, she has amassed a record of 285-96, the most wins and highest winning percentage in school history. In 2006, she led the Lady Yotes to their best season in program history, compiling a 35-4 record - earning CCC and NAIA Region I Coach of the Year honors. The Yotes won their first CCC championship in 24 years, becoming just the second school to complete the league schedule without a loss. The Coyotes also captured their second-straight CCC Tournament title, along with their second-straight NAIA Region I Tournament title, before placing ninth at the NAIA Championships – with that team setting a school-record with 22 straight wins. Her 2012 club will take a 62-match CCC home win streak into the season and have won 84 of their last 86 home matches. Mendiola was an assistant for the Coyotes on two separate occasions – from 1995-96 and from 1999-2000, before elevating to head coach. She has also coached club volleyball at Emmett High, for the Treasure Valley Volleyball Club, the Boise River Volleyball Club, and various camps in the Northwest. A native of Jerome, Mendiola graduated from The C of I in 1996 with a degree in elementary education, and taught kindergarten in Nampa before becoming head coach in 2001. A two-year member of the Coyotes, Mendiola set school records for kills per game (4.86) in 1994, and holds the school mark for kills per game in a career (4.46).

FOR MORE INFORMATION: For more on the Lady Yotes, visit the new official homepage of C of I volleyball, http://www.yoteathletics.com/index.aspx?path=wvball&tab=1.
